answers.answer: Just because a doctor is an Endo does not assure a good thyroid doctor.  Many Endos specialize in diabetes.  For thyroid patients many Endos have the "Immaculate TSH Belief" and use "Reference Range Endocrinology", which does not work for many thyroid patients.  What you need is a good thyroid doctor that will test and adjust the biologically active thyroid hormones, Free T3 and Free T4 as necessary to relieve hypo symptoms.If you will please post your thyroid related blood tests, along with reference ranges shown on the lab report, we can better assess your status, and advise further.

Due to the NHS direction in the UK, the difficulty in getting adequately tested and treated for hypothyroidism is scandalous.  There is much to talk about, but rather than being redundant,  I suggest that you read the posts in this thread from a fellow UK member, and then see what questions you have..http://www.medhelp.org/posts/Thyroid-Disorders/lower-side-free-t4-but-normal-tsh/show/2314689#post_11173773

Ord's thyroiditis results in progressive atrophy (wasting away) of the thyroid gland and over time causes hypothyroidism which generally progresses to complete thyroid failure.  Tissue changes in Ord's thyroiditis shows fibrosis and stunted cell growth.  In European countries, Ord's thyroiditis is more common than Hashimoto's thyroiditis.Diagnostic criteria for Ord's thyroiditis:* Decreased thyroid volume (normal volume: females - 15 to 18 mL; males - 20 to 25 mL)* Ultrasound - hypoechogenic pattern* Reduced technetium uptake in thyroid scintigraphy* Positive thyroid peroxidase antibodies (TPOAb) and/or thyroglobulin antibodies (TgAb)
The thyroid eventually atrophies with Hashimoto's, as well.

Just looked up ords and it seems to be identical to hashimoto except the thyroid wastes away but you say it can with hashimotos  well it should be interesting to hear what the endocrinologist has to say but after19 years I don't hold out much hope  !!!!! Thanks
Hyperthyroid flare ups are rare with Ord's thyroiditis. With Hashimoto's thyroiditis, hyperthyroid flare ups (hashitoxicosis) are most likely to show up in the early stages of the disease.
